ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: knowledge of baroque art, classicism, sculpture, major artists in rome, some formal analysis
I learned to critically analyze pieces of art and to understand how the creater uses various visual techniques to convey a message.
I learned how history of art is studied and how to analyze art.
how to think about and view art in a historical context
I gained a deeper overview of the art scene in Baroque Rome, involving painting, sculpture, and architecture. I also continued to develop my visual description skills.
I learned about the general scope and goals of the Baroque movement
I learned the fundamentals of baroque art, including information about the lives of famous contributors, the style, the inspiration, and the social context.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: strengths: professor suthor is fantastic. many of the images on her lecture slides are photos she has taken herself and she does an excellent job of really giving you a sense of what it's like to physically encounter the art. i found this perspective particularly helpful when understanding baroque sculpture. the tfs were also wonderful. weaknesses: sometimes it's unclear what the takeaway should be from the analysis of a particular piece.
I course material is extraordinarily interesting. However, it is sometimes difficult to take notes given the specificity of each art's analysis.

This course has lots of interesting material. However, the lack of organization made it really hard to learn. Professor Suthor would just kind of go through a bunch of slides every lecture and while her lectures were interesting, I came away from each one not knowing what I was supposed to take away from it. Before the midterm and the final, I basically had to go through all the slides (which only had the paintings on them and no notes) and memorize the artists and the titles and just pray.

This was a wonderful course. The material was highly interesting and presented in an engaging way. The historical background provided made the artistic analyses more meaningful and interesting. I had a great time in the lectures.

The course can at times feel unengaging even though the material is interesting. Some of this has to do with its structure and style, but as an underqualified undergraduate, I am unsure if my feedback is that helpful. With that caveat in place, a suggestion: perhaps a section would make the class more engaging.

Strengths: The course content is incredible and Prof Suthor is extremely knowledgable. She provides ample opportunity to discuss material out of class (you MUST go to one of her close looking sessions in the YUAG, they are optional but extremely well done). 
Weaknesses: This having been said, I think there is less emphasis on the assignments and therefore there was much confusion about due dates/how to approach the papers. I think this could be cleared up with earlier communication. I also think a section could have been helpful for this course because there is so much content it would be helpful to review weekly.
I thought that this class was very well taught and that the lectures were filled with the most interesting paintings and art.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes! professor suthor is wonderful, the assignments and exams are very approachable, and the material is fantastic. suthor really made an effort to organize excursions (trips to yuag, hartford, beinecke, leitner) and engage everyone.
I would highly recommned this course to anyone interested in learning how to appreciate and analyze art.
No, take another history of art course. I had no idea what Baroque Rome was and now that I know, I'm going to forget soon. It wasn't the best ever.
yes!! one of the most interesting and most approachable courses for non-HSAR majors. Loved the TF's and professor Suthor
I would highly recommend this course to another student. The lectures are interesting and tie together well. The workload is very reasonable and develops useful art historical skills.
I would recommend this if a student, like me, is generally interested in art history in Europe.

Yes! I learned a lot from this course. It's definitely not for someone who has not taken an art history course before, as there is little guidance around essays/exams. I cannot imagine how hard this course would be if I hadn't written a visual analysis/done IDs before. However, the time period is extremely interesting and Prof Suthor is an amazing professor!
Yes! Learning about baroque art with Professor suthor was extremely rewarding.
